title: After Celebrating Diwali, Delhi Wakes Up To 'Severe' Air Quality. Stubble Burning Adds To Woes
text:
It’s the day after Diwali and air pollution has touched severe mark in many locations in North India, particularly around the National Capital Territory of New Delhi while most other parts of the country did not signs of being affected.

On late Sunday evening, a layer of haze had blanketed the national capital and its air quality dipped to "very poor" category with revellers continuing to defy with impunity the Supreme Court-enforced two-hour limit for bursting crackers on Diwali.

ANI

Twenty-five of the 37 air quality monitoring stations in the capital had recorded their AQI in "very poor" category or beyond on Sunday evening but what followed was ear-deafening booms, toxic smoke and ash from firecrackers filled the air as the overall air quality index crossed the "severe" mark at many places.

News agency PTI reported violation of the two-hour window in Malviya Nagar, Lajpat Nagar, Kailash Hills, Burari, Jangpura, Shahdara, Laxmi Nagar, Mayur Vihar, Sarita Vihar, Hari Ngar, New Friends Colony, Dwarka among others places.

Residents in Noida, Gurgaon and Ghaziabad also reported extensive fireworks much beyond the time-frame. The people could also be seen bursting crackers before 8 PM, however, the intensity remained low.

With Delhi's air quality plummeting to dangerous levels around Diwali every year, the Supreme Court in 2018 banned polluting firecrackers and ordered that only green firecrackers, which is said to cause 30 per cent less pollution, can be manufactured and sold.

According to reports, stubble burning in Punjab and Haryana have doubled in the last 48 hours, adding to the woes of Delhiites.

But the green pyrotechnics have failed to draw good response both from sellers and buyers, primarily due to lack of variety, limited stock and high prices.

Last year too, people continued to buy the conventional firecrackers and use them.

Whereas Delhi has been impacted once again by pollution during Diwali, other parts of the country were largely unaffected, according to the Centre For Science And Environment (CSE), which quoted data from aqi.in.

Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) had already warned in advance that lighting up even half the fire crackers than in 2018 could pull down AQI to ‘severe’ in Delhi NCR.

Now, the festival is over, we have woken up to exactly that in Delhi and surrounding regions.
